_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary - Coyne Chemical - Reading Plant



George S. Coyne Chemical Co., Inc. is a chemical distributor serving the areas of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, New York, Washington DC, Maryland and Virginia.  In this capacity, Coyne is a re-seller of chemicals to industrial, commercial and municipal customers.  Of the current inventory consisting of approximately 100 types of chemicals, one is considered extraordinarily hazardous under the RMP regulations and is stored above the applicable threshold value.  The facility is located on approximately 4.25 acres and is bordered by a rail siding to the East, a water retention basin on the South, and two other industrial businesses to the North and West. Access can be made to the site by the only entrance off Witman Road on the Southwest side of the facility. 



The chemical on site subject to RMP regulation is:



Chlorine (CAS # 7782-50-5)



Chlorine is also subject to the OSHA PSM regulations (29 CFR 1910.119)





STATIONARY SOURCE IDENTIFICATION



Coyne Chemical has identified the storage of the referenced material as the only stationary source at the facility.  



Chlorine is contained within pre-packaged cylinders containing 150 lbs. of product.  All full and empty cylinders are stored inside a dedicated storage room within the warehouse in storage racks with 16 cylinders per rack. The worst-case release scenario at the facility is a full cylinder release of a chlorine cylinder occurring outside of the facility during the unloading process. This scenario does not take into account any of the passive mitigating systems built into the storage process. Due to the fact that that the chlorine cylinders are stored in storage racks designed to house this type of cylinder, transported in the storage racks or individually secured within the transportation vehicle, and the loading and unloading step is the shortest step of the process, the worst-case scenario is not likely to occur.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE

Coyne employees do not respond or handle chlorine spills, the fire department is immediately contacted. A manager can be reached via the emergency voice mail system whenever the facility is closed in order to organize an emergency response. Coyne has arrangements with outside emergency response personnel to handle all spills of chlorine. The emergency response plan will be coordinated with the County Office of Emergency Management (OEM) and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



It is the policy of the George S. Coyne Chemical Co., Inc. to have programs in place to identify and handle emergency response and public preparedness issues involving products handled at facilities operated by the company, in transit, and during storage and/or use at a customer's site. These programs address the following items deemed critical to achieving this goal:



A.    Documentation, review, coordination and tests of emergency response plans.

B.    Procedures for response, reporting, investigation and implementation of preventative measures with respect to incidents which could have or did result in a release, explosion and/or fire.

C.    Procedures for supplying emergency response information regarding chemicals handled to emergency response agencies and communication with state and local emergency planning and response organizations regarding potential hazards of products handled at facilities.





SECURITY 



An (8) eight-foot tall chain link fence equipped with barbed wire around the top protects the outside boundary of Coyne Chemical.  The Southwest gate serves as the main entrance for all traffic.  This gate is electrically controlled and cannot be opened from the outside without a pass card and remains closed at all times. There is a gate on the East side adjacent to the railroad tracks, but it is kept locked at all times. This gate can be opened if necessary, for emergency response. 



Overhead light fixtures are located on the exterior perimeter of the plant property

as well as positioned along the top of the building to illuminate all exterior areas of the property. All entries to the office and warehouse are secured and monitored by an alarm system.  Movement through the facility is further managed utilizing a key pass system.  In the event of an unauthorized entrance, an alarm is sounded at a central monitoring station, the local police department is dispatched, and a Coyne Chemical manager is notified.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION PROCEDURES



Mitigation for Chlorine scenarios include utilizing a cylinder "A" Kit or placing the leaking cylinder into a containment vessel located on-site.  



The chlorine is stored in a chemical specific room within the warehouse. This room has product-specific detectors with alarms that will trigger in the event of a leak from a cylinder. This alarm triggers a number of passive systems to minimize a release. Coyne utilizes frequent visual inspection to determine the presence of a leak.



Coyne Chemical is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD) and subscribes to its Responsible Distribution Processes.  As part of this process, Coyne Chemical has developed policies and procedures regarding Risk Management, Emergency Response and Security.



It is the policy of the George S. Coyne Chemical Co., Inc. to have programs in place to promote the process of risk assessment and management in relation to the chemicals and services provided by the Company. These programs address the primary goal of continual risk reduction by analysis of the hazards of the chemicals distributed, the likelihood of accidents/incidents, and the impact of these releases on the public and the environment. The Company fully supports and encourages employee participation in the safety programs established and requires strict adherence to the guidelines established for the safe operation of its facilities.



Continuous risk reduction will be encouraged throu

gh the following steps:



A. Product review and hazard assessment,

B. Hazard ranking of the chemicals distributed,

C. Review with manufacturer of products supplied,

D. Incident review and analysis, and

E. Employee training



FIVE (5) YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There has been no on-site release of this chemical within the last 5 years.  





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Coyne Chemical has completed a Process Hazard Analysis with risk assessment for the registered chemical. Coyne has identified the hazards of working with the extraordinarily hazardous substance on site and has developed programs and systems to safeguard against those hazards.  These procedures are subject to a management of change procedure, which allows the facility management to review and upgrade procedures and programs when necessary. Coyne will continue to review the procedures and implement protective solutions to health and safety concerns.  The recommendations for improvement that will be analyzed and implemented as deemed appropriate are:  



1.    Ensure that cylinder coffin and chlorine kit are readily available in a marked and accessible location

2.    Clarify narrative in documents 6003210, 600321R, and 600321RGR, to limit SO2 inventory to less than 32 cylinders (2 racks) which would keep it below the RMP threshold quantity.

3.    Modify height restriction from document 600321R, page II, by removing references about the double stacking of cages - store cages 1-high only

4.    Document the plan for the controlled release of chlorine using the exhaust fan in the event of a spill in the chlorine room

5.    Update maximum inventory of SO2 with a memo/administrative procedure to show it is not stored above the RMP threshold.  Note that up to 6 cylinders may be stored onsite without exceeding the PSM threshold quantity

6.    Review contractor safety performance 

7.    Revise/update form 100776 to include companywide contractor evaluations and orientation polices

8.    Update maintenance and PSM proc

edures to reflect current SOPs

9.    Research methods to modify the spill alarm so it is a different tone than the fire alarm 

10.    Update Initial Incident Report form 101305

11.    Update incident investigation procedure to include requirements from 2017 regulatory updates

12.    Update emergency coordinators

13.    Implement an inspection and maintenance plan/procedure for the manual spill alarm activation stations

14.    Implement a preventive maintenance plan/procedure for the chlorine room exhaust fan

15.    Inform the local fire department of the emergency generator and all components that it energizes

16.    Invite the fire department to participate in a chemical release drill and a site walk through

17.    Ensure the old Cl2 detection system is removed and in accordance with all MOC procedures

18.    Perform a MOC for proposed changes in the EHS department

19.    Add exit signs over emergency exits in gas and oxidizer rooms; Install "Not an Exit" signs where appropriate 

20.    Train employees as needed on updated procedures and alarms
